Hi <@U10Q62R8X>.. We unable to build s390x images from Jenkins using this hyp-z-linuxone-2 machine.. Could you please provide us the build machine.

<@U11NUTP4L> <@U12V3D2P2> : Yesterday we pushed x86 images to hyperledger docker hub account. Observed below error while building images using this node 140.211.168.107 ```03:00:41 Step 1 : FROM openjdk:8
03:00:48 Get <https://registry-1.docker.io/v2/library/openjdk/manifests/8>: unauthorized: incorrect username or password
03:00:48 Makefile:217: recipe for target 'build/image/javaenv/.dummy' failed
03:00:48 make: *** [build/image/javaenv/.dummy] Error 1
03:00:48 Build step 'Execute shell' marked build as failure
03:00:49 Finished: FAILURE ```

resolved above issue after deleting `./docker/config.json` file.. but I am getting below error on v0.6.1 latest `GIT_COMMIT=e728c5c2` ```14:07:54 Step 2 : RUN wget <https://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-2.12-bin.zip> -P /tmp --quiet
14:07:54  ---> Running in 2e2a1214ec3f

14:07:54 rpc error: code = 2 desc = "oci runtime error: exec format error"
14:07:54 Makefile:217: recipe for target 'build/image/javaenv/.dummy' failed
14:07:54 make: *** [build/image/javaenv/.dummy] Error 1```

Hi Ramesh
That is the issue with Java SHIM
Hence I had pushed a PR 1671 to comment out the Java SHIM build for power
ok got you..

<@U0KPFAZNF>, need your help on this please. I was suggested by <@U0KM61BCP> to connect with you on the tag that needs to be used for baseimage. But I see that even for ccenv, we are using latest baseimage and there is no specific tag used

sure
<@U11NUTP4L> the problem is that you probably want to use the template engine to actually generate the tag properly
the problem is I think this was done in the master branch, not v0.6
let me look
oh wait, maybe it _is_ available there
if you write it like this: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/images/ccenv/Dockerfile.in>
wait no
sorry, you want baseimage
now I recall: you want essentially whats happening here:
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/images/ccenv/Dockerfile.in>
problem is, the supporting substrate is in master, not v0.6
sorry, my bad.. I was referring to src image and not   ccenv
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/images/src/Dockerfile.in>
this is what I used as template
right, but the problem is that wont work as you expect
Hmm.
baseimage and src are “special” in that they are intermediate artifacts of the build
ccenv and javaenv are different in that they need to stand on their own
thinking some more
if you follow fabric-src as a template, this _might_ work in v0.6…it def will not in master/convergence, etc
but that might be good enough for all intents and purposes
Yes. I agree. This patch will only be for v0.6
On master, I would be using the baseimage tag as it is picked up from baseimage.git
ok…let me think about it a little more, but if the logic is restricted to v0.6 and refactored for master+, I think I am ok with that
Yes. its only for v0.6 for time being so that we can get 0.6.1 images pushed for ppc64le
on master, you would want to do something like ccenv (<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/images/ccenv/Dockerfile.in>)
Ok.
So do I need to do anything more to 1671 now for v0.6 ?

merged
i rebased v0.2.0 proposed tag on top
after it goes through CI, ill lobby for merging/release

The release file is the tag
It's just only official if Makefile::IS_RELEASE = true

<@U0YJUECE8|silliman> has joined the channel
yeah, sorry
it looks a little convoluted but it was done that way so that the version number can be consumed in multiple places
also, I would normally have something like “-snapshot” as a suffix, but that isnt supported in vagrant
so, I am stuck with official looking tags even for “snapshot” builds
but the IS_RELEASE/git-tag is authoritative

<@U0KPFAZNF>, so i hope you don't mind... i've updated the setup.sh and Makefile within the fabric-baseimage repo and copied any s390x or ppc64 specific installations/tailoring that was in the old baseimage logic (within the fabric repo itself).  i'm testing it now.  i'm thinking of submitting a PR for this work.

Hi. I try to build a docker image for the Raspberry PI. In order to stand on the shoulder of giants I try to port the Dockerfile from <https://github.com/yeasy/docker-hyperledger/blob/master/Dockerfile> . By building the  rocksdb lib I encountered this error here: <https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/810> which is fixed in a never version. I wonder why the Dockerfile  is using this old version of the rocksdb.

attachments.title: g++: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-momit-leaf-frame-pointer’ · Issue #810 · facebook/rocksdb · GitHub
attachments.text: OS:Raspberry Pi 2 uname -a 4.1.7-v7+ #817 SMP PREEMPT Sat Sep 19 15:32:00 BST 2015 armv7l GNU/Linux g++ -v Using built-in specs. COLLECT_GCC=g++ COLLECT_LTO_WRAPPER=/usr/lib/gcc/arm-linux-gnueabih...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: g++: error: unrecognized command line option ‘-momit-leaf-frame-pointer’ · Issue #810 · facebook/rocksdb

<@U2ALHGKK4> the peer needs to have access to create/run docker containers itself, as this is what the chaincode instances will execute under....as such, you need to either a) share the /var/run/docker.sock with the peer container with a volume mount (e.g. -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock), or to b) point the peer to a network accessible instance via the CORE_VM_ENDPOINT environment variable
(CORE_VM_ENDPOINT defaults to /var/run/docker.sock, which is why you are seeing that error

Hi, we found some unexpected behavior of using hyperledger image.
When we do `make peer-image` it seemed the image contains a fixed value that we actually don't need, and this leads to a problem that we cannot get the container_id correctly from within the container itself.
(please see the issue, <https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/29127>)

So, the problem is from here, during the build process of HL image
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/scripts/provision/docker.sh#L100>
It grabs all the existing ENVs, including HOSTNAME, from the base image to the newly built image, so that's why we have the problem.

We fixed the issue by skipping the HOSTNAME during built time.
So, please let me know is there any reason to carry the HOSTNAME together with the image?

attachments.title: Container ID and Hostname are not the same. · Issue #29127 · docker/docker · GitHub
attachments.text: Description I used to be able to access the current running ContainerID within the container itself by using an environment variable HOSTNAME (v. 1.12~) However, in the current version 1.13.0-rc2, ...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: Container ID and Hostname are not the same. · Issue #29127 · docker/docker

In v1.0 architecture, Peer docker image compiled has Fabric-Runtime which is built with only busybox. Do we have the peer docker file changes which can also build /bin/bash in the compiled peer-docker?
<@U3M7LEDT4> we have not published 1.0-preview images
we have published v0.6.0-preview and v0.6.1-preview which is the latest
if you are trying to run a sample of 1.0, then you will need to build from source

I regret that currently we are working on getting the documentation up to speed with where the code is... recommend that for initial experimentation that you leverage the Starter Kit from v0.6.* release <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/v0.6/starter/fabric-starter-kit/>
<@U3DKG7M54> we were trying to keep the images as stripped down as possible... is there a reason that /bin/sh is inadequate?

<@U3DKG7M54> the challenge is that we want the images to be as small as possible.  One way to do that would be to leverage alpine and install the optional bash package....the problem is alpine docker images are only available for x86 when we need to support other architectures too (like ppc64le and s390x)
so, rather than using alpine, we build a busybox distro from scratch
the benefit is we can compile it for all the necessary platforms, the bad part being we lose niceties like being able to trivially install a package like bash
that said, it would not be hard for you to create a different docker image as a one-off
i can help you if this is of interest
for instance, you could change L1 from here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/images/peer/Dockerfile.in#L1>
to ..

Thanks Greg [@ghaskins], Chris <@U0KM61BCP> for your response. I am using v1.0 images built from master branch and trying to use different option like running Peer CLI options, modifying Peer yml for which I require bash prompt. Do we have substitute to run this activities?
that image wasnt really intended to be used that way
its only meant to deploy a validating peer
that said, it _should_ work if you use /bin/sh instead
(I think)
e.g. "docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-peer /bin/sh" should get you a prompt in which "peer XXX" cli commands work
but as I indicated above, it was not built with this mindset
my suggestion would be to use the fabric-peer image as a deployment vehicle for the peer binary, and use something else like a native build for CLI
that way, you would have the expected environment for the CLI, dev, etc
as far as modifying the core.yml, I would suggest either using environment overrides, volume mounting a new /etc/hyperledger/fabric, or deriving a new image (in that order)
for instance, say you have a customized core.yml, you could do something like "docker run -it -v path/to/custom/core.yml:/etc/hyperledger/fabric/core.yml hyperledger/fabric-peer"
(im actually not sure if you can volume mount a file or only dirs, you would have to experiment
but you get the idea
i digress: the short of it is: I intended the /etc/hyperledger/fabric dir to be volume-mount replacable
yes - on the docker volume and shell.
can u clarify on ' and use something else like a native build for CLI '?
well, what i do for instance is "make native" and use the "peer chaincode" commands natively on mac
as an example
I only use the fabric-peer docker container to run the actual network, not drive the CLI
Ok w/o the dockerizing it.
right
you certainly can use the docker, its just more awkward in a CLI capacity
for instance, "docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-peer peer chaincode deploy .." would work
but that is a handful
plus, you might need to add volume mounts to access local chaincode, etc
i think for CLI, it makes more sense to operate natively
note to self: implement "make install" so people can easily build/install the native binaries
a related side note: this was not as important within vagrant because by default "make native" results in binaries in ./build/bin, which is added to the $PATH in vagrant
but this wouldnt be the case outside of vagrant without specific user action
the right/standard way to do this would be to provide an install target
so I will do that
the other thing - the OS run for native peer test will be important. I use RHEL and the default built docker-peer image uses Ubuntu.
someone is working on that
that reminds me, I owe him a review
let me find the CR
<@U3DKG7M54> can I ask why this is important to you?
one explanation I have heard that makes sense was surrounding certification/compliance/support, but I can't think of any other reasons
Im just curious what is driving this requirement
before - did u meant from the above lines, the shell terminal will also be unavailable in default-peer image?
L2/3 support was 1 reason - but mounting can be less secure exposing the file.
not sure what you are referring to, but I do not anticipate we will remove /bin/sh
I went through all that work to put custom busybox in because I think we minimally want that level of environment in any image
can you elaborate on what you mean by "mounting can be less secure exposing the file" and also the places where the OS choice matters
for example, the final result for -peer and -orderer images is devoid of distro
so I dont see that it matters in that case
however, we do use ubuntu for building
are you saying volume mounting the config is less secure as a production option?
I will be back 30-60mins. Sorry.
np
anyway, for when you return: do note that you have full power to enact whatever change you want
for instance, you could create a new Dockerfile that does "FROM hyperledger/fabric-peer" and then change things the way you want
or, just change fabric.git, etc
its purely a question of whether the change should be pushed back upstream in terms of coordinating here
<@U3DKG7M54> I found the work I was referring to above: <https://github.com/jkilpatr/fabric-baseimage-2.0>

<@U2TD4Q7NW|jkilpatr> has joined the channel

<@U0KPFAZNF>,  had to drop my kid. 

The discussion started as I did not find the bash terminal to enter in the container. Having shell makes me proceed for running peer, changing configuration. 

Other points that came up:
Verifying chaincode on peer via native approach will always be on top of mind saying tested on RHEL distro however my chaincode will be finaly running in QA cycle on cc-env having ubunu-x.x release. 

On the docker volume, this is good for DEV environment but going in to higher environment release like JAS/Production this will expose files like configuration. Having advantage from docker container of not exposing the volume by default is an additional security layer, would prefer to be used.
regarding cc-env, don't read too much into the current setup
I plan on giving the final chaincode deployment the same minimalist treatment
so, hopefully soon, if not by 1.0, chaincode will not "run" on ubuntu
but rather, it will be a stripped down busybox
that said, until something like <@U2TD4Q7NW> 's work is integrated, we will be building peer and chaincode on ubuntu
not sure if this is still a problem
regarding docker volumes, I am still not clear on the issue you are raising
are you saying that relying on volume mounts to reconfigure /etc/hyperledger/fabric is a problem?

<@U0KPFAZNF>  I was a bringing up case a l2 support requiring to change any peer configuration like batch size, the prefered would be not exposing yml on to the host using docker volume rather let them login into the container via -exec and then running the required system repair steps.
ok, but I would still argue a few counter points
1) volume mounts seem to be an acceptable secrets/configuration vehicle established in other orchestration layers (see Kubernetes)
2) you have multiple options to express config as it is
3) you can always derive from and/or modify the containers to suit your requirements
so I am not sure any action is needed in an upstream sense
am i missing anything?
to be clear: if there is some change that would make the upstream more conducive to that model in a way that is generally applicable, I have no problem considering it
I am just not seeing a need (yet)
and separate Q: when we say we added only busybox layer to the fabric-runtime image, doesn't it need minimalistic OS files for running?
nope :slightly_smiling_face:
all that is technically needed is the peer/orderer binary
its statically linked, and in fact, will run perfectly fine in a "FROM scratch" docker container
I only added busybox because, that is _too_ stripped down and you cant get in an poke around
i explain the rationale more completely here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/commit/b61723f9ddcc91cafd4f3a8c3634bd8d32388b32>

attachments.title: [BUILD] Minimize docker container sizes · hyperledger/fabric@b61723f · GitHub
attachments.text: We use two techniques: 1) the use of a minimal docker base (FROM scratch + busybox) 2) the use of a static binary ... to create a minimally sized image for 'peer' and 'orderer' Before this patc...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: [BUILD] Minimize docker container sizes · hyperledger/fabric@b61723f

text: perhaps this is already understood but a docker image is really just the FS component....all the runtime stuff like /proc and the kernel-interface are surfaced by the docker runtime
so, the image only needs to have whatever files (ignoring synthetic files like /proc, /sys, /dev) your application needs
since these are -static binaries, they need nothng

<@U3CBDC0JG|kenzhang> has joined the channel

Hi, I am getting error when running "make dist-clean all":

`ERROR: for vp  b'No such image: sha256:f409834569e5b0d1207b1c27da1540c4e5a389961840e428d8e6cec9fb0c0f8a'
ERROR: Encountered errors while bringing up the project.
make: *** [unit-test] Error 1`
does anyone know when/how this image `sha256:f409834569e5b0d1207b1c27da1540c4e5a389961840e428d8e6cec9fb0c0f8a` is built?
<@U3CBDC0JG> I think the issue is in docker-compose
try this
cd unit-test && docker-compose down
and then try again
I have seen this before...the best I can describe it is that "docker-compose up" persists some state even after the composition exits
normally its not a problem, but if you then also "make clean" it orphans those resources and compose gets confused on subsequent operations
however, running " ... down" fully cleans those up
I am not sure what the best long-term fix is
but this is a known workaround
<@U0KPFAZNF> thx, will try this next time. I fixed it be removing all of the existing aborted container
ok, yes, that is essentially what ... down does

cd unit-test && docker-compose up --abort-on-container-exit --force-recreate && docker-compose down should be changed to :

cd unit-test && docker-compose up --abort-on-container-exit --force-recreate; docker-compose down
compose needs the equivelent of "--rm'
as in docker-run
ah, yes, that is a good observation
that is indeed a bug that would lead to this happening
which would make sure the docker-compose down is run whenever the previous cmd exists, currently if previous cmd fails, down won't get executed
yep, i agree
it might need even further refinement, but that is a step in the right direction
that might actually mute the failure though
agree. if the cmd fails before docker-compose up, the "down" would be cleaning nothing, I guess for now it's as u said, a step in the right direction :slightly_smiling_face:
the issue is we need the error to propagate out so things like CI know the process failed
but you are on to something
one thought: we could do the down before the up (and get rid of the --force-recreate
uh, ic, we need to keep the exit code
yeah
that's for sure doable :slightly_smiling_face:
kinda hacky though
anyway, give it some more thought
i think your observation is astute, now we just need to find a good solution
surprised the "--force-recreate" is not cleaning up properly
yeah, that was my attempt to beat it over the head
i think that did improve things in certain circumstances, but a few were still slipping through (probably what you just found)
if you happened to have a test failure AND did a clean, blammo
honestly, its probably partly a docker-compose bug too
because I agree the force-recreate should obviate caring
I would recommend some kind of convention, either by naming,  namespace, tag, etc, on both the image and container name, to make the clean up easier
not following: as best I can ascertain, we already do
for instance, the typical image has -snapshot-$sha in it already
or did you mean something else?
it seems, to me, part of the problem is that docker-rmi is allowed to pull the rug out from under docker-compose
i think that is likely a bug in docker/compose
uh, right, sorry
for the $sha part, it makes "docker ps" really hard to read
my perception is that docker-compose is only maintaining a weak reference to the container SHA
and rmi is free to GC it, leaving the reference dangling until the next time it tries to re "up"
I would have thought --force-recreate basically ignores the previous reference, but that doesnt always appear to be the case
im confused though, I thought you were advocating for more precise naming
are you saying it should be more generic
like if we always used peer:latest rather than peer:....-snapshot-$sha" ?

wish I have the images so that I can show you, and I can't remember exactly. there are cases (I think it's the chain code container) where the image name is really long, it scrambles the "docker ps" output and make it really hard to read
maybe we can come up with a shorter version of $sha?
we are already using the short-name, i think the sha isnt really the problem though
its the entire tag
i mean, the sha is adding more, yes, but overall the tag is fairly long to begin with
actually I am looking now, it seems the tag isnt displayed anyway
(in docker-ps output, i mean)
can you elaborate on where the problem comes up?
<@U0KPFAZNF|ghaskins> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3PAW5V9T/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: This is what I see right now

initial_comment.comment: This is what I see right now

text:
The docker containers that are created to run chaincode have names that include the hash of the chaincode source code and as well as any deployment parameters (my understanding anyway).

Example: dev-jdoe-example01-0-48baa00e355e6db1648cff44e28f1dbf322523a99ffe283fd99a00348466eb78075559488e372409bb691aab29cfa894645c9c2737781367012e0c816eb227b7
Ah yes, that could be what <@U3CBDC0JG> is talking about
<@U0YK3KKCY> thx, yes that's what I am referring to
<@U3CBDC0JG> I'm not sure whether you can control the chaincode container names or not
docker image/containers supports lables, we could use that to store the SHA if it's only for informational purpose
you have some control over some components of the name, but I'm not sure about the hash part

I had a general question. I have set up a network of peers on a VM using docker compose  .each  peer is running on different container..now if I deploy a chaincode then I see tht it creates 4 chaincode images and 4 chaincode containers on the host machine. So my question is does all this 4 chaincode containers takes 4*times the size of each CC container? or they are just soft links pointing to a single storage?
<@U12AHQ3NK> its shared
you only pay for the cost of the baseimage once, and then the deltas of the 4 containers
<https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/storagedriver/imagesandcontainers/>

attachments.title: Understand images, containers, and storage drivers
attachments.text: Learn the technologies that support storage drivers.
attachments.fallback: Docker: Understand images, containers, and storage drivers

text: <@U0KPFAZNF> thanks...why is the size of CC container and peer container nearly same when  CC deployed for firts time.?  way makes the CC container to grow tht big?
i assume you are running in v0.6?
if so, both peer and cc are derived from the same baseimage
and that baseimage has a superset of substrate for compiling and running all aspects of fabric
go, nodejs, protoc, etc
but, as noted above, you really only pay for like 99% of the heft once
in master, things improve a bit...the peer image (and other runtimes) are tiny
right now, even in master, the chaincode containers are still coupled to baseimage so they will be a bit large

I do expect to eventually treat the cc runtimes to the same diet...that said, note that practically speaking you'll still always have the cost of the bigger image as the peer would need to compile the CC in the large image (that has the compiler, libraries, etc, necessary for compilation)
so, in summary, the cost of the large image will sort of always be there to some degree, but its more readily apparent in the older arch
but thankfully, it looks much worse than it really is on account of how docker works

okay...so <@U0KPFAZNF>  how would the storage Change if VMs are used instead of Docker containers? I guess If the CC are running in the same peer VM process and will thus comprome isolation but would storage become effective here as compared to Dockers?
if you architected your system to use vms, then only you would know what that would look like
if you run it the way upstream fabric works, then you would pay the baseimage cost once and then it would be small incrememtal costs per chaincode on top
(rough guess, on the order of 20MB per chaincode instance
right now, that baseimage cost is approx 1.4GB
so 1.4G + X*20M gives you a size estimate
where X is the number of instances you expect to have
I do expect that 1.4G to come down, too
but it wont be too dramatic, perhaps more like 512M-750M
and wat abt the peer containers? If I increase peers from 4 to 15 then each peer wil share the storage?
are you running the peers on the same host?
Yes
then you just pay it once
and like I said, theres a relationship to the cc container
so its really the 1.4G once
and then a small incremental for the peer binary (once, ~25MB) and a small incremental per chaincode instance ~20MB)
so, if you had 10 peers and 20 chaincode instances on one host, I would expect that to look something like 1.4G + 10*25M + 20*20M
make sense?
ops
sorry
no scaling on peer cost
<@U0KPFAZNF>  thts great...
if you did "docker images" it would look like 31 images of 1.4G each
but they are almost all sharing space
(1 for baseimage, 10 for peers, 20 chaincodes)
so now if the CC state increases would tht 20M per CC instance increase just once or x times?
to be clear, this has nothing to do with state
this is the cost of the docker containers, which is .text only
how much or how little state is a completely different topic
you also have storage which by default is written to /var/hyperledger
you would need to account for that too
ohh...but over the time tht storage should increase right?
i would expect it to, that is the nature of blockchains
ya.  So int case each peer container wil aso consume more memory x no of times where x is number of peers. is it so?
i would expect so yes, but you were asking about docker sizes which is orthogonal
each peer would have its own storage requirements in terms of blockchain state, and that is true regardless of docker architecture
<@U0KPFAZNF> ..thanks it was very helpful
np
the other thing I noticed tht I have been using yeasy- docker images for fabric and they take around 823 MB for v0.6
how is this image size different from hyperledger ones?
I would ask yeasy

Hi, My hyperledger works perfectly fine in NOOPS with 4 peers. Wanted to confirm. When I make any changes via ROOT NODE it is replicated to all peers and I can see messages or data posted in all the individual ledgers. But when I post any data via peer it only happens between peer and root node and no other peers are updated. Is this correct behaviour ?
<@U0W7D64LC|markparz> has joined the channel
<@U3SCKQB4P> it isn't correct, but you might do better using pbft consensus as noops was really intended just as a no-op fake consensus. It was not intended to be used for anything substantive.
